Learn how to choose between DynamoDB and: Learn how to choose between DynamoDB and RDS for different query scenarios in MBC CQRS Serverless.
This guide helps you understand when to: This guide helps you understand when to query DynamoDB directly versus RDS (via Prisma) in the MBC CQRS Serverless framework.
In the CQRS pattern, write operations (c: In the CQRS pattern, write operations (commands) and read operations (queries) are handled separately with different data stores optimized for each purpose.
Write operations go through `CommandServ: Write operations go through `CommandService` to DynamoDB Command Table
DynamoDB Streams trigger Data Sync Handl: DynamoDB Streams trigger Data Sync Handlers
Data is synchronized to both DynamoDB Da: Data is synchronized to both DynamoDB Data Table and RDS
Get by key, Query by partition key with: Get by key, Query by partition key with sort key conditions
Single-digit millisecond latency, automa: Single-digit millisecond latency, automatic scaling, no connection management
No JOINs, limited filtering, no full-tex: No JOINs, limited filtering, no full-text search
Complex filters, JOINs, aggregations, fu: Complex filters, JOINs, aggregations, full-text search
Flexible querying, relational integrity,: Flexible querying, relational integrity, powerful filtering
Connection management needed, requires D: Connection management needed, requires Data Sync Handler setup
Use this matrix to quickly determine whi: Use this matrix to quickly determine which database to query:
Get single item by pk + sk: Get single item by pk + sk
List items by pk with sk prefix: List items by pk with sk prefix
Do you have pk and sk?: Do you have pk and sk?
Query by pk with sk condition only?: Query by pk with sk condition only?
Example 1: Single Item Lookup - Use Dyna: Example 1: Single Item Lookup - Use DynamoDB
When you have the exact pk and sk, use D: When you have the exact pk and sk, use DataService for fast, direct access.
Direct key lookup - DynamoDB is optimal: Direct key lookup - DynamoDB is optimal
Example 2: List by Partition Key - Use D: Example 2: List by Partition Key - Use DynamoDB
When listing items that share the same p: When listing items that share the same pk with a sort key filter, use DataService.
List all orders for a tenant - efficient: List all orders for a tenant - efficient pk-based query
List order items using sk prefix: List order items using sk prefix
When you need to filter by multiple attr: When you need to filter by multiple attributes, use Prisma for SQL-powered queries.
Build dynamic WHERE clause - RDS excels: Build dynamic WHERE clause - RDS excels at this
Execute count and find in parallel: Execute count and find in parallel
DynamoDB does not support full-text sear: DynamoDB does not support full-text search. Use RDS for text search queries.
Full-text search across multiple fields: Full-text search across multiple fields - only possible with RDS
When you need to combine data from multi: When you need to combine data from multiple tables, use RDS with Prisma relations.
JOIN order with order items - requires R: JOIN order with order items - requires RDS
Aggregate with GROUP BY - only possible: Aggregate with GROUP BY - only possible with RDS
For optimal performance, use both databa: For optimal performance, use both databases based on the query type.
Use DynamoDB for single item by key: Use DynamoDB for single item by key
Add indexes on frequently queried column: Add indexes on frequently queried columns
To query data from RDS, you must impleme: To query data from RDS, you must implement a Data Sync Handler that synchronizes data from DynamoDB to RDS.
